hawaiian_text: A pau ka pule ‘ana a Nāmakaokapāo‘o, i ia wā i  ‘o‘oki ai ‘o Puali‘i i ke ko‘ilipi i luna pono o  Nāmakaokapāo‘o, e ho‘ohuli aku ā nā ‘oi o ke ko‘i  iā Puali‘i, moku ke po‘o, a ‘ōlelo mai i kahi ‘ē. Pane  mai ke po‘o o Puali‘i iā Nāmakaokapāo‘o: “Aloha  ‘oe, e Nāmakaokapāo‘o.” Lālau akula ‘o   Nāmakaokapāo‘o i ke po‘o o Puali‘i a kiola akula i  kai o Waipouli, he ana ma kahakai o Honouliuli, ‘o  kona loa, ‘elima mile ka loa.
llama4-maverick-fireworks_translation: After Nāmakaokapāo‘o finished praying, at that time Puali‘i struck Nāmakaokapāo‘o right on top of the head with an adze, so that the sharp edge of the adze turned toward Puali‘i, severing his head, and he spoke from another place. The head of Puali‘i responded to Nāmakaokapāo‘o: "Aloha to you, Nāmakaokapāo‘o." Nāmakaokapāo‘o seized the head of Puali‘i and threw it into the sea at Waipouli, a cave on the shore of Honouliuli, which is five miles long.
llama4-maverick-fireworks_commentary:
The passage provided is a narrative from Hawaiian oral tradition, likely from a mo‘olelo (historical or legendary account) or a ka‘ao (legendary tale). The story revolves around a confrontation between two figures, Nāmakaokapāo‘o and Puali‘i, and involves elements of violence, supernatural occurrences, and geographical references.

Culturally, this passage reflects several key aspects of Hawaiian tradition and society. Firstly, the use of an adze (ko‘i) as a weapon is significant. Adzes were not only tools used for woodworking and other crafts but also held spiritual and ceremonial importance. The fact that the adze turns against Puali‘i, severing his head, may symbolize a form of divine retribution or the manifestation of spiritual power (mana). The severed head continuing to speak is a motif found in various Polynesian cultures, often signifying the power and mana of the individual even in death.

The exchange of "aloha" between Nāmakaokapāo‘o and the severed head of Puali‘i is also noteworthy. "Aloha" is a complex term that encompasses love, compassion, and greeting. In this context, it may be interpreted as a sign of respect or acknowledgment between the two characters, despite their adversarial relationship.

Linguistically, the passage is rich in traditional Hawaiian vocabulary and grammatical structures. The use of "i ia wā" to indicate the timing of events ("at that time") is characteristic of narrative devices used in Hawaiian storytelling to sequence events. The verb "‘o‘oki" (to strike or chop) followed by "i luna pono" (right on top) provides a vivid image of the action. The phrase "e ho‘ohuli aku ā nā ‘oi o ke ko‘i" illustrates the use of causative verbs ("ho‘ohuli" to cause to turn) and the incorporation of specific terms for parts of tools ("nā ‘oi" referring to the sharp edge), showcasing the detailed and nuanced nature of the Hawaiian language.

Historically, the passage references specific geographical locations, such as Waipouli and Honouliuli, which are associated with the island of O‘ahu. Honouliuli is known as an ahupua‘a (land division) on the leeward coast of O‘ahu, indicating that the narrative is tied to specific places and potentially to the history or legends of that area. The mention of a cave ("ana") at Waipouli, described as being on the shore, adds to the geographical and cultural detail, as caves often held spiritual or practical significance in ancient Hawaiian society.

The length of the cave, described as being "‘elima mile ka loa" (five miles long), is a notable detail. While this might be an exaggeration or a metaphorical expression, it underscores the significance of the location and possibly its perceived extent or importance.

Overall, this passage offers insights into Hawaiian cultural practices, linguistic nuances, and historical or legendary narratives. It highlights the complexity and richness of Hawaiian oral traditions and the importance of understanding these stories within their cultural and historical contexts.

reference_translation: When Nāmakaokapāo‘o ended his prayer, Puali‘i  struck at Nāmakaokapāo‘o with the adze right on  top of his head, but the blade of the adze turned  towards Puali‘i and his head was cut off. From a  distance, the head of Puali‘i said to   Nāmakaokapāo‘o, “Goodbye, Nāmakaokapāo‘o.”  Nāmakaokapāo‘o took the head of Puali‘i and  threw it in the sea at Waipouli, a cave on the  beach at Honouliuli, which was five miles long.
reference_commentary: **Paragraph 9:**• While the abandonment of the ‘Ai Kapu and the rise  of Christianity are historical, Pua-li‘i’s attack of Nā- maka-o-ka-pāo‘o does not seem to have a correlating  historical reference. The ‘Ai Kapu was abandoned in  1819 and the first Christian missionaries arrived in  Hawai‘i in 1820, with a full year in the interum of no  organized religion to replace the ‘Ai Kapu. While  many Hawaiians were stubbon to adopt Christianity  and resented it, Christianity spread quickly and  overwhelmed any pro-‘Ai Kapu sentiment by the end  of the 1820s. If Pua-li‘i here represents the ‘Ai Kapu  and Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo‘o represents Christianity, and  the adoption of Western culture in a more broad  sense, this event in the story seems to misrepresent  the ‘Ai Kapu as savage, impulsive, and violent against  Christianity, culminating in a single event. There is no  such historical single event recorded in history;  • By a twist of fate, the adze Pua-li‘i wielded to cut off  the head of Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo‘o somehow turned  against the wielder, cutting off the head of Pua-li‘i,  which Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo‘o tossed into the ocean at Wai-pouli (water of darkness), a cave in Hono-uliuli  (bay of darkness) in ‘Ewa, O‘ahu, a distance of five   miles away. This ironic demise of Pua-li‘i signifies the  ultimate defeat of the ‘Ai Kapu by Christianity and/or  progressive ambitions, but this violent event has no  parallel in Hawaiian history. This could be viewed as  an embellishment as a type of Christian progaganda.  • The five-mile long toss of Pua-li‘i’s head by  Nāmakaokapāo‘o was an emphasis on the boy’s  superhuman physical strength.
